title: Semantic Commit Messages with Conventional Commits
content: Standardized format for Git commit messages using Conventional Commits specification. Format: <type>[optional scope]: <description>. Types: feat (features), fix (bug fixes), docs (documentation), style (formatting), refactor (restructuring), test (tests), chore (maintenance), perf (performance). Rules: Type required and lowercase, scope optional, description in imperative mood, body explains WHAT/WHY, footer for breaking changes.
description: Standardized format for Git commit messages that clearly communicates the intent and type of change. Based on Conventional Commits specification.
problemSolved: Inconsistent commit messages make project history hard to read, automate changelog generation difficult, and reduce team collaboration efficiency.

rules: Type is required and must be lowercase
Description is required, imperative mood ('add' not 'added')
Footer (optional) for breaking changes or issue references
examples: fix: resolve memory leak in cache layer
chore: update dependencies to latest versions

steps: Install commitlint and husky if not present
Set up git hook to validate commits
Train team on commit types and format

validation: Commit messages follow '<type>: <description>' format with valid types and imperative mood
